study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the importance of adjunctive skincare, including emollients, in managing acne-prone skin and mitigating adverse effects from acne treatments.
results_summary: The study found that emollients, as part of adjunctive skincare, can help manage acne-prone skin by replenishing the skin barrier and reducing irritation. Moisturizers with emollients, humectants, and anti-inflammatory properties were highlighted as beneficial.
population_specificity: Individuals with acne-prone skin, particularly those using systemic or topical acne medications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of topical emollients in managing chemotherapy-associated Grover disease, particularly in cases where standard treatments are ineffective.
results_summary: The study found that topical emollients, often combined with topical steroids, are the first-line treatment for chemotherapy-associated Grover disease, though some cases require alternative therapies. Emollients were generally effective, but recalcitrant cases necessitated more specialized approaches.
population_specificity: Patients with chemotherapy-associated Grover disease (a subset of cancer patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cutaneous side effects of EGFR inhibitors and assess the effectiveness of treatments, including emollients, for managing these side effects.
results_summary: Emollients were used as part of the treatment regimen for acneiform rashes caused by EGFR inhibitors, alongside topical and systemic antibiotics. The study reported mild to moderate skin side effects, with all patients completing chemotherapy, suggesting emollients contributed to symptom management.
population_specificity: 59 patients (47 females, 12 males) with breast, colorectal, or renal cancer receiving EGFR inhibitor therapy.
study_duration: Follow-up occurred at weeks 1 and 2 after treatment initiation, with the study conducted over two years (February 2016–February 2018).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review structural variances in black skin related to pruritus and discuss clinical management strategies, including the use of emollients.
results_summary: The study found that black skin has unique structural properties exacerbating pruritus, and emollients were recommended to diminish trans-epidermal water loss as part of management.
population_specificity: Black patients with chronic pruritic disorders.

study_goal: To evaluate Amerchol L101 as a marker of lanolin allergy and assess the clinical impact of lanolin-containing moisturizers on healthy and damaged skin using the repeated open application test (ROAT).
results_summary: The study found that 92% of test subjects had positive patch test reactions to Amerchol L101, but no skin reactions occurred during ROAT on intact skin, and all participants healed on damaged skin. Lanolin-containing emollients did not cause or worsen dermatitis in volunteers patch test positive to Amerchol L101.
population_specificity: Twelve test subjects and 14 controls, including individuals with irritant dermatitis induced by sodium lauryl sulfate (SLS).
effective_dosage: Twice daily application of lanolin-free cream base and two different lanolin-containing test creams.

study_goal: The researchers did not assess emollients; the study focused on pharmacological interventions for intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy.
results_summary: The abstract does not mention emollients; it primarily evaluates ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) and other pharmacological treatments for intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy.
population_specificity: Women with intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of nanotechnology-based therapies, including emollients, to improve skin hydration, barrier repair, and drug delivery for atopic dermatitis (AD) treatment.
results_summary: The study highlights that conventional emollients and moisturizers face limitations like low skin penetration and insufficient maintenance, but nanotechnology-based systems (polymeric, lipid-based, inorganic) show promise as effective drug-delivery systems for AD by enhancing hydration and barrier repair.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on atopic dermatitis patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing mild atopic dermatitis and compare their safety and efficacy with other treatments.
results_summary: Emollients were found to be effective for managing mild atopic dermatitis, with a favorable safety profile compared to systemic immunosuppressants, which have significant toxicities. Severe cases required more aggressive treatments like biologics.
population_specificity: Patients with mild atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of daily topical application of hyperoxygenated fatty acids emulsion on transcutaneous oxygen pressure (TcPO₂) in diabetic patients to prevent foot ulcers, particularly in neuroischaemic feet.
results_summary: The study found that patients with neuroischaemia showed a significant increase in TcPO₂ after using the emulsion, suggesting potential benefits for preventing diabetic foot ulcers. The results indicate improved oxygenation in the targeted population.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetes and no active foot ulcer, specifically those with neuroischaemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the unmet need for safe and effective long-term therapies for pediatric atopic dermatitis (AD), including the limitations of current treatments like emollients.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that emollients are among the current modalities that inadequately manage moderate to severe pediatric AD lesions, highlighting the need for more effective treatments. No specific efficacy data on emollients are provided, but their inclusion as a standard treatment suggests modest effectiveness.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in the maintenance therapy of atopic dermatitis, focusing on their effectiveness in managing symptoms and improving quality of life.
results_summary: The study found that liberal use of emollients, along with daily bathing with soap-free cleansers, is a key component of maintenance therapy for atopic dermatitis, helping to manage symptoms and prevent flare-ups.
population_specificity: Individuals with atopic dermatitis (atopic eczema).

study_goal: The study did not evaluate emollients; it focused on the efficacy of a weight-loss program with a ketogenic diet for chronic plaque psoriasis.
results_summary: The study did not report any findings related to emollients.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese, drug-naïve adult patients with stable chronic plaque psoriasis (excluding topical emollients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy and safety of various treatments, including emollients, for hereditary palmoplantar keratoderma (hPPK) since 2008.
results_summary: Emollients were among the topical treatments used to relieve symptoms in hPPK, but the abstract does not provide specific efficacy data for emollients alone. The study notes that oral retinoids appear most efficient, though not universally effective or well-tolerated.
population_specificity: Patients with hereditary palmoplantar keratoderma (hPPK).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in treating cutaneous barrier dysfunction in atopic dermatitis (AD) as part of a broader treatment strategy.
results_summary: The study highlights that emollients are a key component in managing AD by addressing skin barrier dysfunction, alongside anti-inflammatory treatments and lifestyle adjustments. The guidelines recommend their use based on clinical research, emphasizing their role in breaking the cycle of inflammation and irritation.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD) in Japan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in preventing food allergy in children with atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: Early skincare with emollients was identified as a promising strategy to prevent food allergy in children with atopic dermatitis, alongside topical steroids and early introduction of allergenic foods. The abstract highlights the potential benefits but does not provide detailed efficacy data.
population_specificity: Infants and children with atopic dermatitis, particularly those at risk of developing food allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to outline guidelines for the diagnosis, prevention, and treatment of chronic hand eczema, emphasizing early management by primary care and occupational health physicians.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the importance of early diagnosis, protective measures, and appropriate referral to specialists for managing chronic hand eczema but does not provide specific results regarding emollients.
population_specificity: Patients with hand eczema, particularly those in primary care and occupational health settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if regular skin emollients applied from 2 weeks of age reduced the development of atopic dermatitis by age 12 months in the general infant population.
results_summary: The study found that neither skin emollients nor early complementary feeding reduced the development of atopic dermatitis by age 12 months, with no significant difference in risk compared to the control group. No safety concerns were identified, and skin symptoms were not more frequent in the intervention groups.
population_specificity: Infants from the general population, enrolled from birth to 12 months of age.
effective_dosage: Emollients (bath additives and facial cream) applied on at least 4 days per week.
study_duration: From 2 weeks of age to 12 months.

study_goal: To assess the effects of hygiene and emollient interventions for maintaining skin integrity in older people in hospital and residential care settings.
results_summary: The study found very low-quality evidence suggesting emollients may reduce skin tears and dryness, but results are uncertain due to methodological limitations. No clear differences were observed in transepidermal water loss or stratum corneum hydration.
population_specificity: Older people aged ≥60 years in residential care settings (mean age 80+ years, predominantly women).
effective_dosage: Varied by study (e.g., twice-daily moisturiser, daily body wash with emollients, single hot towel application).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the features, etiopathogenesis, and management options for pruritus in pediatric atopic dermatitis, emphasizing the role of emollients and a multidisciplinary approach.
results_summary: The study highlighted emollients as a traditional therapy supported by European guidelines and advocated for therapeutic patient education and distraction techniques to improve quality of life. It stressed the need for individualized strategies tailored to patient age and clinical features.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with atopic dermatitis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and analyze existing treatment options for Kyrle's disease, including the role of emollients in combination therapies.
results_summary: Emollients were mentioned as part of combination therapies for Kyrle's disease, but no specific efficacy data or standalone results were provided for emollients alone. The study noted that combination regimens, which may include emollients, are commonly used but lacked definitive recommendations.
population_specificity: Individuals with Kyrle's disease, particularly those with underlying chronic renal failure or diabetes mellitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop consensus-based guidance for managing adverse events associated with lenvatinib, including skin toxicities managed with emollients.
results_summary: The study recommended using moisturisers or emollients and soap substitutes to manage skin toxicities caused by lenvatinib. No specific efficacy or safety data for emollients alone were provided.
population_specificity: Adults with progressive, locally advanced or metastatic, differentiated thyroid carcinoma refractory to radioactive iodine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss the multidimensional treatment of Atopic Dermatitis, including the role of emollients, and propose a new step-by-step approach for disease control and quality of life improvement.
results_summary: The abstract highlights emollients as part of the treatment for Atopic Dermatitis, alongside other therapies like topical steroids and calcineurin inhibitors, but does not provide specific results on their efficacy. The paper emphasizes a comprehensive approach to managing AD, including addressing immunological dysfunction and environmental triggers.
population_specificity: Children and adults with Atopic Dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the tolerance and efficacy of a high-emollient liquid cleanser (HELC) for very dry and atopic-prone skin, focusing on dermatological and ophthalmological safety and moisturizing effects.
results_summary: The study demonstrated good dermatological and ophthalmological tolerance of HELC, with improvements in SCORAD and moisturizing scores, indicating efficacy in reducing skin dryness and pruritus. The product was well-accepted by subjects.
population_specificity: 50 subjects (infants, children, and adults) with dry to very dry and atopic-prone skin.
effective_dosage: At least once daily on face and body (specific volume not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of barrier emollients in treating perianal pruritus among patients with common anorectal conditions.
results_summary: Barrier emollients were recommended as part of the treatment for perianal pruritus, alongside hygienic measures and low-dose topical corticosteroids. The abstract suggests emollients are effective, particularly when combined with other treatments, though recalcitrant cases may require additional therapies like capsaicin cream or tacrolimus ointment.
population_specificity: Patients with perianal pruritus, a common anorectal condition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients as a supportive measure in managing balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO) in boys.
results_summary: The study mentions emollients as part of supportive measures for BXO but does not provide specific efficacy data. Their use is highlighted alongside other treatments like topical steroids and immune modulators.
population_specificity: Boys with balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO), average age 8 years (range 1-16).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify clinical characteristics and risk factors for eczema herpeticum (EH) and recurrent EH, including the role of prior treatments like emollients.
results_summary: The study found that pretreatment with plain emollients was part of standard therapy for EH, but it did not specifically evaluate their efficacy or safety. Skin without AD lesions was never affected by herpetic lesions.
population_specificity: 224 EH cases from eight European centers, primarily patients with extrinsic atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to map expert opinion on the clinical management of moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis in Nordic countries, including the role of emollients in treatment sequences.
results_summary: Emollients were recommended as part of a treatment sequence for moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis, following topical glucocorticosteroids and preceding systemic treatment if necessary. Patient education was identified as essential for effective management.
population_specificity: Adults with moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis in Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current pharmacological treatments, including emollients, for cutaneous manifestations in inherited ichthyosis and explore novel therapeutic approaches.
results_summary: The study highlights that emollients are part of current treatments for ichthyosis, but no definitive cure exists. It suggests nanotechnology-based formulations could enhance therapeutic effectiveness.
population_specificity: Patients with inherited ichthyosis (syndromic and non-syndromic types).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in a proactive management approach for pediatric psoriasis, focusing on maintaining therapeutic efficacy and preventing relapse.
results_summary: The study suggests that emollients, alongside skin hygiene and other proactive measures, can help reduce the risk of relapse in pediatric psoriasis, though specific efficacy data is not detailed.
population_specificity: Children with psoriasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of an anti-inflammatory moisturizer (MAS062D lotion) versus a hydrophilic cream in improving skin hydration and barrier function in elderly patients with xerosis.
results_summary: Both treatments significantly improved xerosis severity, but MAS062D lotion showed superior skin hydration and transepidermal water loss reduction compared to hydrophilic cream, with no serious adverse effects reported.
population_specificity: 24 Thai elderly patients (mean age 58.04 years, 87.5% female) with moderate to severe xerosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in treating cutaneous barrier dysfunction in atopic dermatitis (AD) as part of a broader treatment strategy.
results_summary: The study highlights emollients as a key component in managing AD by addressing cutaneous barrier dysfunction, alongside other treatments like corticosteroids and tacrolimus ointment. The guidelines emphasize optimizing patient outcomes through evidence-based recommendations.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD) in Japan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of emollient V0034CR and its active ingredients on restoring the cutaneous barrier and assessing moisturizing activity and tolerance.
results_summary: V0034CR significantly reduced TEWL compared to vehicle and vehicle + glycerol, and significantly increased skin moisture compared to vehicle and vehicle + petrolatum, demonstrating combined barrier improvement and hydration effects.
population_specificity: 51 healthy volunteers with dry skin (Kligman score of 2 or 3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of family constellation seminars (FCS) combined with emollients in reducing itch and improving skin condition in patients with atopic dermatitis (AD) and psoriasis.
results_summary: The study found that FCS combined with emollients significantly reduced itch severity in both AD and psoriasis patients, with notable improvements in AD skin condition (SCORAD) but less significant changes in psoriasis (PASI). The positive effects increased over 9 months.
population_specificity: Thirty-one adult patients with chronic itch (16 with AD and 15 with psoriasis).
effective_dosage: Not specified (only emollients were used, no dosage details provided).
study_duration: 3 months (FCS intervention), with follow-up to 9 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness and safety of laxatives, including emollients, in older populations for constipation management.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on emollients but notes a general lack of evidence regarding the effectiveness or safety of most laxatives in older populations.
population_specificity: Older adults with constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of emollients in addressing dry skin, itch, and barrier damage, and how recent advances in understanding itch mechanisms could improve topical therapies.
results_summary: The study highlights that emollients are a primary treatment for dry skin and itch, with recent advances enabling new topical therapies to be integrated into existing regimens. It emphasizes the need for personalized treatment approaches.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on skin barrier damage and itch).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether emollients, alone or in combination with synbiotics, could prevent atopic dermatitis (AD) and food allergy (FA) in children during their first year of life.
results_summary: The study found that neither emollients nor synbiotics, alone or combined, reduced the development of AD or FA by 1 year of age. No significant preventive effect was observed.
population_specificity: Babies from birth up to 1 year of age, with prenatal recruitment of mothers.
study_duration: From birth up to 6 months of age

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the dermatological toxicities associated with panitumumab, including the use of emollients as a preventive treatment, and their impact on quality of life.
results_summary: Emollients were administered as a preventive treatment to 75.5% of patients, alongside oral antibiotics, and were part of a regimen that showed a reduction in dermatological toxicities over time, with limited impact on quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients over 18 years with wild-type KRAS metastatic colorectal cancer initiating panitumumab treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the evidence on the effectiveness and role of emollients in reducing atopic eczema severity and their steroid-sparing effects.
results_summary: The study found that emollients reduce atopic eczema severity, have steroid-sparing effects, and lead to better outcomes when combined with topical corticosteroids compared to corticosteroids alone. However, there was little comparison of different emollients in randomized controlled trials.
population_specificity: Individuals with atopic eczema (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and safety of UVA1 phototherapy in treating moderate to severe plaque-type psoriasis by assessing clinical and histological outcomes.
results_summary: UVA1 phototherapy showed significant improvement in PASI scores by 1-month post-treatment, but histological changes were minimal. The treatment was well-tolerated, with skin tanning as the most common side effect.
population_specificity: 15 patients with moderate to severe plaque-type psoriasis (skin type IV).

study_goal: The researchers were evaluating crisaborole as a newer treatment for mild to moderate atopic dermatitis, comparing its efficacy and safety to existing therapies like emollients.
results_summary: The abstract highlights crisaborole as an efficacious topical agent with a favorable safety profile, but does not provide specific findings on emollients.
population_specificity: Children and adults with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential benefits and drawbacks of adding emollients, oils, and other additives to bath water for managing atopic dermatitis in children.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that regular bathing hydrates the skin and removes irritants, but it remains unclear whether adding emollients or other substances provides additional benefits for atopic dermatitis management. The study will review current evidence on this topic.
population_specificity: Children with atopic dermatitis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the methodology, acceptability, and efficacy of an ectoin-containing emollient for atopic dermatitis (AD) compared to other proprietary emollients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in AD severity, quality of life, and transepidermal water loss after four weeks of using the ectoin-containing emollient, though no significant changes were observed in itch, sleep, skin hydration, or S. aureus colonization. Acceptability was rated as "very good" or "good" by 63% of participants, with some reporting a 'tingly' sensation.
population_specificity: 30 subjects (50% male, mean age 9.8 years) with moderate to severe atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence for various oral vitamins and supplements, including emollients, for the treatment or prevention of atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: The study found that emollients, along with vitamins E and D, have robust evidence for managing AD symptoms, while probiotics may help prevent infantile AD. Fatty acids like docosahexaenoic acid, sea buckthorn oil, and hempseed oil showed preliminary evidence for reducing AD severity, but more randomized controlled trials are needed.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD), including infants for probiotic studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if applying a ceramide-dominant emollient twice daily from birth to 6 months reduces the risk of atopic dermatitis (AD) and food allergy in infants with a family history of allergic disease.
results_summary: The abstract does not report results, as the study was ongoing at the time of publication. Outcomes were to be assessed at 12 months, including AD presence, food allergy, and secondary measures like skin barrier function.
population_specificity: Infants (n=760) with a family history of allergic disease, recruited from maternity hospitals in Melbourne.
effective_dosage: Ceramide-dominant emollient applied two times per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure the out-of-pocket costs associated with atopic dermatitis (AD) treatment, including the use of emollients, in adult patients.
results_summary: Emollients were the most commonly used product (74.4% of patients), with an average out-of-pocket cost of €151.4 annually. The study found that out-of-pocket costs increased significantly with AD severity.
population_specificity: Adult patients with atopic dermatitis cared for in four French hospitals (n=1024).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of interventions, including emollients, for infantile seborrhoeic dermatitis in children aged 0-24 months.
results_summary: One trial found lactamide MEA gel (a moisturizing agent) plus shampoo improved severity scores compared to shampoo alone, but evidence quality was very low. No adverse events were reported for emollient-related treatments.
population_specificity: Infants and young children (0-24 months) with clinically diagnosed infantile seborrhoeic dermatitis or cradle cap.
effective_dosage: Not specified for emollients (lactamide MEA gel used in one trial, but exact dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in providing symptomatic relief for genitourinary syndrome of menopause (GSM).
results_summary: The abstract indicates that emollients are a mainstay treatment for GSM, offering symptomatic relief, but does not provide specific efficacy data. Newer treatments like ospemifene and vaginal lasers are mentioned as alternatives.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women and postmenopausal breast cancer survivors with GSM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether improvements in epidermal function through topical emollient use could prevent psoriasis relapse.
results_summary: The study designed two self-controlled cohort trials to assess the effects of an in-house-prepared emollient or ATOPALM on psoriasis patients, but specific efficacy results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriasis (n = 30 and n = 60 in two cohorts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing chronic pruritus as part of a step-wise, guideline-driven therapeutic approach.
results_summary: Emollients were recommended as an initial therapy for chronic pruritus, often in combination with topical corticosteroids if appropriate. If these measures failed, systemic therapies were suggested, but the abstract does not provide specific efficacy data for emollients alone.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic pruritus, often refractory to conventional therapies.

study_goal: To assess whether providing hand creams, electronic monitoring, and feedback on cream consumption could improve skin care adherence among healthcare workers.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased self-reported cream use before and during shifts compared to the control group, though application frequency remained below recommended levels. Electronically measured use averaged 0.4 events per shift per HCW in the intervention group.
population_specificity: 501 healthcare workers across 19 academic hospital wards.
effective_dosage: Not specified (cream use monitored but not quantified per application).

study_goal: To determine the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of emollient bath additives in the management of childhood eczema.
results_summary: The trial found no evidence of clinical benefit from including emollient bath additives in standard eczema management. Both groups showed similar outcomes in eczema control, severity, and quality of life measures.
population_specificity: Children aged 12 months to 12 years with active eczema (excluding very mild cases) from general practices in Wales, the west of England, and southern England.
effective_dosage: Not specified (prescribed by usual clinical team, used regularly).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of the skin microbiome in atopic dermatitis (AD) and assess the impact of treatments, including emollients, on restoring a healthy microbiome.
results_summary: The study suggests that emollients and topical corticosteroids positively influence the skin microbiome in AD patients, supporting their use in treatment regimens. Initial results are promising but require further validation.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the importance of patient and family engagement in managing atopic dermatitis (AD) through the use of emollients and action plans.
results_summary: The study found that frequent emollient use is essential for managing xerotic skin in AD patients, and action plans can effectively integrate into overall care instructions, improving patient/family engagement.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD), particularly younger patients requiring parental or family assistance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acceptability and practicality of collecting weekly measures of eczema severity online for 16 weeks in children using bath emollients as part of standard eczema care.
results_summary: The study found that weekly online completion of eczema severity measures was feasible and acceptable, with high data completeness (83% of time points) and no socio-demographic bias. Parents/carers generally understood the rationale, though some found weekly questionnaires burdensome while others considered them quick and easy.
population_specificity: Children aged 1 to 11 years with eczema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of emollients as a natural therapy for atopic dermatitis (AD) compared to other treatments.
results_summary: The study found that emollients are the safest and most effective natural agents for AD, with fewer risks compared to other treatments like Chinese herbals and Ayurvedic agents, which have significant safety concerns.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis, including children and their parents seeking therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a combination of a topical cleansing product and an emollient cream containing colloidal oatmeal, avenanthramides, shea butter, and oat oil in improving symptoms of xerosis and atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: The study found improvement in epidermal thickness, skin dryness, itching, and cracking after one month of using the oat-based cleanser and lotion. Colloidal oatmeal was shown to safely reduce itching, irritation, and dry skin severity while restoring skin barrier function.
population_specificity: Patients with xerosis and atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing atopic dermatitis (AD) as part of a broader treatment strategy before considering systemic therapy.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that emollients, alongside corticosteroids and phototherapy, are part of the initial treatment approach for AD, but systemic agents may be necessary if these measures fail to achieve adequate disease control.
population_specificity: Adults and children with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of emollients in treating atopic dermatitis (AD) compared to other topical and systemic treatments.
results_summary: The study found little evidence that ceramides or natural moisturizing factors (components of emollients) provide relief in AD, suggesting limited efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (specific age groups not detailed for emollients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cost-effectiveness of dupilumab versus usual care with emollients in treating moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: Usual care with emollients had lower lifetime costs ($271,500) compared to dupilumab ($509,600), but dupilumab provided additional quality-adjusted life years (QALYs). The incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) for dupilumab was $124,500, indicating higher costs for improved outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis inadequately controlled with topical therapy or for whom topical therapies were medically inadvisable.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of skin barrier dysfunction in atopic dermatitis and explore treatment strategies, including the early use of emollients in high-risk infants.
results_summary: The study suggests that early use of emollients in high-risk infants may help prevent atopic dermatitis and potentially halt progression to related comorbidities like food allergy and asthma.
population_specificity: High-risk infants (for atopic dermatitis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the importance of basic skin care, including emollients, and describe current and novel topical therapies for atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: The study found that emollients are recommended for adequate skin hydration and restoration of the skin barrier in AD, alongside other measures like antibacterial treatments and anti-inflammatory drugs. Emollients help alleviate symptoms and improve quality of life, though no curative treatment exists for AD.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of emollients as a treatment option for chronic itch in end-stage renal disease patients.
results_summary: The study found that emollients, along with other therapies like phototherapy and systemic treatments, provided significant relief for varying percentages of patients with chronic itch in end-stage renal disease. No specific efficacy data for emollients alone was detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with end-stage renal disease suffering from chronic itch.

study_goal: To determine the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of including emollient bath additives in the management of eczema in children.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in eczema control between children using emollient bath additives and those not using them, with no clinically meaningful benefit observed. Secondary outcomes, economic outcomes, and adverse effects also showed no differences between the groups.
population_specificity: Children aged 1 to 11 years with atopic dermatitis, excluding those with very mild eczema or who bathed less than once weekly.
effective_dosage: Not specified (prescribed by usual clinical team for regular use).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the role of emollients in the management of mild forms of DRESS syndrome.
results_summary: The study mentions emollients as part of the treatment for mild DRESS syndrome, alongside antihistamines, but does not provide specific efficacy data.
population_specificity: Patients with mild DRESS syndrome (no further specificity provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of silicone gel and onion extract gel in reducing the appearance of new surgical scars.
results_summary: After 12 weeks of treatment, both silicone gel and onion extract gel showed similar efficacy in scar reduction, with no significant differences in objective or subjective assessments. Safety and compliance were comparable between the two groups.
population_specificity: 60 subjects with laparoscopic surgical scars.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and anti-inflammatory properties of emollients, particularly those containing Rhealba oat plantlet extract, in improving skin barrier function and addressing microinflammation in atopic dermatitis (AD) patients.
results_summary: Emollients, especially those with Rhealba oat plantlet extract, were found to improve skin barrier function and exhibit anti-inflammatory properties. They are recommended for all AD patients, with proactive therapy combining emollients and anti-inflammatory treatments for moderate to severe cases.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD), including those with moderate to severe cases and seemingly healed lesions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review therapy options, including emollients, for managing chronic pruritus in elderly patients (≥65 years).
results_summary: Emollients were recommended as part of a step-wise symptomatic therapy for chronic pruritus, particularly for dry skin, with an emphasis on individualized treatment balancing risks and benefits.
population_specificity: Elderly patients aged 65 or older with chronic pruritus, often with comorbidities and polypharmacy.

study_goal: The researchers were examining the effectiveness of emollients and topical steroids in treating hypopigmented flat-topped papules in a pediatric patient.
results_summary: Emollients and topical steroids showed no improvement in the patient's condition, leading to a referral for further dermatological evaluation. The study ultimately diagnosed the condition as clear cell papulosis, which required no treatment due to its benign and asymptomatic nature.
population_specificity: A 12-month-old boy with hypopigmented flat-topped papules on the suprapubic skin and lower abdomen.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how long-term emollient use affects skin microbiota, skin pH, and atopic dermatitis (AD) development in infants at risk for AD.
results_summary: Emollient use lowered skin pH and increased bacterial diversity, particularly Streptococcus salivarius, which was associated with reduced AD incidence. S. salivarius proportions were inversely correlated with AD severity in a separate older population.
population_specificity: 6-month-old infants with a family history of atopy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of serlopitant, a substance P/neurokinin 1 receptor antagonist, in treating chronic pruritus, with emollients used as adjunct therapy.
results_summary: The study found that serlopitant at 1 mg and 5 mg doses significantly reduced chronic pruritus compared to placebo, with no significant safety or tolerability differences. Emollients were used alongside midpotency steroids but their specific effects were not isolated.
population_specificity: Patients with severe chronic pruritus refractory to antihistamines or topical steroids.
effective_dosage: Emollients were used as adjunct therapy; specific dosage not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether early-life emollient use could prevent atopic dermatitis (AD) and potentially reduce the risk of subsequent food allergies and allergic airways disease.
results_summary: The study found a strong link between early-life AD and later allergic diseases, with emerging evidence suggesting that prophylactic emollient use can significantly reduce AD expression. Ongoing trials are exploring whether this reduction might also lower the incidence of food allergies and allergic airways disease.
population_specificity: Infants, particularly those with early-onset or severe atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review systemic drugs in development for atopic dermatitis (AD), focusing on novel therapeutic approaches targeting immune pathways, while excluding certain traditional and alternative therapies.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that most AD patients are sufficiently treated with emollients combined with existing therapies, but treatment failure remains a clinical problem. New drugs under development target specific immune pathways, potentially offering more effective and less harmful systemic therapy options.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: To assess whether the regular use of emollients reduces the severity of atopic dermatitis (AD) in children with mild-to-moderate AD.
results_summary: The study found that regular use of emollients (V0034CR and reference emollient) significantly reduced AD severity compared to no emollient use, as measured by SCORAD, PO-SCORAD, and POEM scores. A higher percentage of patients in the emollient groups achieved complete remission compared to the no emollient group.
population_specificity: Children with mild-to-moderate atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the association between emollients and allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) in patients with atopic dermatitis (AD), including common allergens and the role of patch testing.
results_summary: The study highlights that ACD is a significant comorbidity in AD patients, with common allergens like lanolin, fragrances, and formaldehyde found in personal care products. It reviews the indications and challenges of patch testing in AD patients but does not provide specific efficacy or safety data on emollients.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD), including children and adults.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of therapeutic patient education on the understanding and successful use of emollients in Chinese children with atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvement in knowledge about emollient use and greater reductions in AD severity and quality of life scores compared to the control group. No significant difference was found in Children's Dermatology Life Quality Index scores between groups.
population_specificity: Chinese children aged 2-14 years with moderate to severe AD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of emollients in preventing atopic dermatitis in infancy and their potential role in interrupting the allergy march.
results_summary: Two randomized controlled trials demonstrated successful prevention of atopic dermatitis in infancy using emollients, though longer-term safety and impact on allergy progression require further study.
population_specificity: Infants at risk for atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy and recent patents of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM), including emollients, in treating Atopic Dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: The abstract notes that evidence for the efficacy of CAM, including emollients, in treating AD is generally lacking, with only a few RCTs evaluating Chinese medicinal herbs and other CAM modalities.
population_specificity: Patients with Atopic Dermatitis (AD), including children and their families.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current and emerging topical treatments, including emollients, for atopic dermatitis, focusing on efficacy and safety profiles.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that emollients, when used in combination with topical corticosteroids, are a mainstay treatment for mild to moderate atopic dermatitis, though adherence issues and side effects of corticosteroids remain a concern. Novel therapies are being developed to improve efficacy and reduce adverse effects.
population_specificity: Children and adults with mild to severe atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients as a first-line intervention for Atopic Dermatitis (AD) and compare their efficacy with other treatments like phototherapy.
results_summary: Emollients are highlighted as a first-line treatment for AD, alongside corticosteroids and calcineurin inhibitors, but the abstract focuses more on phototherapy's efficacy and safety rather than detailed outcomes for emollients.
population_specificity: Patients of all ages, genders, and ethnicities with Atopic Dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients as a non-pharmaceutical treatment for managing pruritus in atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: Emollients, when used with wet wraps, were recommended as a first-line non-pharmaceutical treatment for pruritus in atopic dermatitis. The abstract suggests they are part of an initial therapeutic approach before pharmacological interventions are considered.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis experiencing pruritus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of a corticosteroid-free cream containing starch, glycyrretinic acid, zinc oxide, and bisabolol in children with chronic mild-to-moderate atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The cream significantly reduced the total eczema severity score (TESS) by 51% at 3 weeks and 74% at 6 weeks, with 87% of subjects achieving at least a 50% reduction in TESS. The product was very well tolerated, with only one mild adverse event reported.
population_specificity: 30 children (mean age 5 years) with chronic mild-to-moderate atopic dermatitis affecting face, limbs, or trunk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of emollients and other treatments for managing atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The study found that emollients and topical corticosteroids are effective for most patients with atopic dermatitis and are commonly used by dermatologists. Severe cases may require additional immunomodulatory medications or targeted therapies like dupilumab.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing atopic dermatitis (AD), particularly their efficacy in maintenance therapy and prevention of mild disease progression.
results_summary: The study suggests that emollients are beneficial for maintenance between flares and preventing mild AD progression, though prescription treatments may be more effective for moderate to severe cases or during flares.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (general, no specific subgroup mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in treating atopic dermatitis (AD) by reducing cutaneous inflammation and alleviating pruritus.
results_summary: Emollients were identified as an effective part of topical therapies for AD, contributing to decreased inflammation and symptom relief, though the abstract does not provide specific efficacy data for emollients alone.
population_specificity: Adults and children with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update the consensus on inverse psoriasis therapy, including the role of emollients as a second or third-line treatment.
results_summary: The study found that emollients are considered a second or third-line therapy for inverse psoriasis, alongside antimicrobials and tar-based products, but did not provide specific efficacy data for emollients alone.
population_specificity: Patients with inverse psoriasis involving skin fold areas.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of emollients in controlling mild to moderate atopic dermatitis (AD) and discuss emerging biologic therapies for severe AD.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that emollients are effective in controlling mild and moderate forms of atopic dermatitis, though severe cases remain challenging. The focus shifts to biologic drugs like dupilumab and crisaborole for severe AD.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild to moderate atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of dietary interventions with pre- and/or probiotics alongside emollients and/or local corticosteroids for the treatment of atopic dermatitis in children.
results_summary: Some dietary interventions with pre- and/or probiotics showed benefits in managing atopic dermatitis in children when used alongside emollients and/or local corticosteroids, though study heterogeneity was high.
population_specificity: Children with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients as part of first-line therapy for managing hand eczema in patients with atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The study found that emollients, when combined with topical corticosteroids, are recommended as first-line therapy for hand eczema in atopic dermatitis patients, with alternatives like topical calcineurin inhibitors or coal tar also considered.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis and hand eczema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily application of emollients in the first year of life could prevent atopic eczema (AE) in high-risk infants.
results_summary: The abstract describes the study protocol but does not report results, as it is a trial in progress.
population_specificity: High-risk term infants (first-degree relative with asthma, AE, or allergic rhinitis) in England.
effective_dosage: Daily application (specific product or amount not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily application of emollient moisturizers from birth could protect susceptible infants from developing atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: The study found that daily application of an emollient moisturizer from birth appears to protect susceptible infants from developing AD, suggesting a simple and effective preventive intervention.
population_specificity: Susceptible infants (those with a family history of atopy, genetic predisposition, or exposure to tobacco smoke).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing chronic pruritus, particularly in preventing xerosis, as part of a broader therapeutic approach.
results_summary: The study highlights emollients as a basic measure for managing chronic pruritus, emphasizing their use to avoid xerosis regardless of symptom duration. It positions emollients alongside other topical and systemic treatments but does not provide specific efficacy data for emollients alone.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic pruritus due to dermatological, systemic, neurological, or psychiatric conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of silk garments (DermaSilk) as an adjunct to standard care, including emollients, for managing atopic eczema in children.
results_summary: The study found that adding silk garments to standard eczema care, including emollients, did not significantly improve eczema severity or prove cost-effective compared to standard care alone. Patient-reported outcomes and quality of life measures also showed no meaningful benefit from the silk garments.
population_specificity: Children aged 1-15 years with moderate or severe atopic eczema.
effective_dosage: Not specified (standard care included emollients, but exact usage details were not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of oral bacterial lysate OM-85 as an adjuvant therapy alongside conventional emollients and topical corticosteroids in treating atopic dermatitis (AD) in children.
results_summary: The study found that OM-85 significantly reduced and delayed new flares of AD compared to placebo, with no major side effects reported. The treatment showed good tolerability and efficacy as an adjuvant therapy.
population_specificity: Children aged 6 months to 7 years with confirmed atopic dermatitis diagnosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare treatment strategies for atopic dermatitis (AD) between dermatologists and non-dermatology specialties, including the use of emollients.
results_summary: Dermatologists were more likely to prescribe emollients for AD compared to non-dermatology specialties, suggesting a difference in treatment approaches. The study did not specifically evaluate the efficacy of emollients but noted their higher usage by dermatologists.
population_specificity: Outpatient visits for atopic dermatitis (AD) in the U.S. from 1993-2010, including both adult and pediatric patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of dietary fiber in modulating intestinal inflammation and its potential impact on colorectal cancer (CRC) prevention.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that low intake of dietary fiber is associated with increased intestinal inflammation, which may contribute to CRC development, but does not provide specific efficacy data on fiber supplementation.
population_specificity: General discussion on intestinal inflammation and CRC, not specific to a defined population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if β-hydroxy-β-methylbutyrate (HMB) supplementation could maintain muscle mass and reduce immune and inflammatory responses in combat soldiers during intense military training.
results_summary: HMB supplementation significantly lowered tumor necrosis factor-α and was very likely to reduce other inflammatory markers (granulocyte colony-stimulating factor, interleukin 10) while likely increasing muscle volume in the adductor magnus compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Combat soldiers undergoing highly intense military training

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare dietary intakes, including fiber, between an electronic cohort study and a nationally representative survey to assess generalizability.
results_summary: The study found similar intakes for macronutrients and total energy but noted differences in fiber intake between the two cohorts. Specific details on fiber's effects were not fully elaborated in the abstract.
population_specificity: 49,443 French volunteers aged 18-74 years from the NutriNet-Santé Study and 2,754 French adults from the ENNS survey.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of carbohydrates, particularly fiber, in childhood functional gastrointestinal disorders (FGIDs), assessing both their potential to cause symptoms and their therapeutic efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that soluble fiber supplementation demonstrated efficacy in childhood FGIDs, while evidence for restricting individual carbohydrates was weak. Emerging evidence suggests broader restriction of fermentable carbohydrates (FODMAPs) may be effective.
population_specificity: Children with functional gastrointestinal disorders (FGIDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of oral α-cyclodextrin (α-CD), a soluble dietary fiber, on blood lipid and lipoprotein levels in healthy human subjects.
results_summary: α-CD was well tolerated with minor gastrointestinal symptoms reported in 8% of subjects. It showed a modest reduction in small LDL particles (10%) and improvements in fasting plasma glucose (1.6%) and insulin resistance index (11%).
population_specificity: Healthy males and females aged 18-75.
study_duration: 12-14 weeks per treatment arm with a 7-day washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether heat-stabilized rice bran (SRB) and cooked navy bean powder (NBP) could modulate gut microbiota and metabolites, potentially influencing colorectal cancer risk.
results_summary: Both SRB and NBP increased gut bacterial diversity and altered microbial composition, but only SRB reduced the Firmicutes:Bacteroidetes ratio and increased short-chain fatty acids (SCFA) in stool at 14 days, though not sustained at 28 days.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese volunteers with a prior history of colorectal cancer.
effective_dosage: SRB (30 g/day) or NBP (35 g/day) consumed daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of fiber supplementation, alone or in combination with other treatments, in improving symptoms of symptomatic uncomplicated diverticular disease.
results_summary: The study found that fiber supplementation (Plantago Ovata Husk), when combined with other treatments (rifaximine or mesalamine), led to a statistically significant improvement in bowel movement frequency and symptom patterns in patients with diverticular disease. Groups receiving fiber showed better outcomes compared to those without fiber.
population_specificity: 178 patients (mean age 71.7±11.5 years) with symptomatic uncomplicated diverticular disease, confirmed by prior colonoscopy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess vision-specific quality of life (QOL) in patients with a history of acute optic neuritis (ON) and recovery of visual acuity (VA) to 20/40 or better, and how QOL scores relate to retinal nerve fiber layer (RNFL) and ganglion cell layer (GCL) thickness and low-contrast letter acuity (LCLA).
results_summary: Patients with a history of ON and "good" visual recovery (20/40 or better VA) still had significantly reduced vision-specific QOL scores compared to controls, reflecting underlying retinal axonal and neuronal loss and visual dysfunction despite maximal high-contrast VA recovery. These deficits were clinically meaningful and correlated with reduced RNFL and GCL thickness and LCLA performance.
population_specificity: Patients with a history of acute optic neuritis (ON) and recovery of visual acuity to 20/40 or better (n = 113), compared to disease-free controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of resistant starch (a type of dietary fiber) in modulating the gut microbiota, particularly in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that prebiotic supplementation, including resistant starch, can beneficially modulate the gut microbiota in CKD patients, though few studies have specifically analyzed its effects in this population.
population_specificity: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the ergogenic effects of nitrate supplementation are linked to specific effects on vascular, metabolic, and contractile function in Type II muscle.
results_summary: The study suggests that nitrate supplementation increases circulating nitrite concentration, with potential benefits for Type II muscle function under hypoxic conditions, but does not provide conclusive results on ergogenic effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (implied focus on Type II muscle function)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether l-rhamnose and inulin, as dietary fibers, could inhibit appetite and influence metabolic responses like insulin secretion.
results_summary: The study found that l-rhamnose significantly lowered postprandial insulin response but did not affect appetite measures, while inulin showed no significant effects on appetite or metabolic markers despite inducing colonic fermentation.
population_specificity: Healthy unrestrained eaters (n = 13)
study_duration: 6-day run-in followed by a single-day intervention

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze differences in short-chain fatty acid (SCFA) development across multiple individuals exposed to partially hydrolyzed guar gum (PHGG) and assess variations in gut microflora fermentation.
results_summary: PHGG increased SCFA concentrations in the distal intestine, but production varied significantly among individuals (2-fold differences). Gas and SCFA levels fluctuated widely, with one donor showing quicker fermentation. The average SCFA ratio (30:45:25 acetate:propionate:butyrate) matched other fermentable fibers.
population_specificity: Six fecal donors aged 23-68.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined supplementation of l-alanyl-l-glutamine and polyunsaturated fatty acids improves exercise performance, muscle function, lean body mass, and quality of life in patients with chronic stable heart failure.
results_summary: The study found no improvement in exercise performance or muscle function but observed increased lean body mass and improved quality of life in the treatment group. Molecular analysis showed no changes in muscle fiber composition, metabolic gene expression, or oxidative capacity.
population_specificity: 31 patients with chronic stable heart failure
effective_dosage: l-alanyl-l-glutamine (8 g/d) and polyunsaturated fatty acid (6.5 g/d)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of creatine supplementation on muscle total Cr content, anaerobic performance, and potential benefits for aerobic endurance and clinical conditions.
results_summary: Creatine supplementation was found to increase muscle total Cr content and enhance anaerobic performance, with some evidence of indirect benefits for aerobic endurance through improved thermoregulation. Efficacy varied based on factors like dose, age, muscle fiber type, and diet.
population_specificity: General human population, with some focus on clinical conditions and exercise performance.
effective_dosage: Loading dose of 20 g/day for 5-7 days, followed by 2-5 g/day maintenance; alternative regimen of 0.3 g/kg/day.
study_duration: Varied, including short-term (5-7 days) and long-term (up to 1 year).
interactions: Enhanced uptake when taken with carbohydrate and protein and/or during exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of β-hydroxy-β-methylbutyrate (HMB) in enhancing mitochondrial biogenesis, skeletal muscle fiber type transformation, and overall muscle function.
results_summary: The study found that HMB supplementation increases PGC-1α gene expression, promoting mitochondrial biogenesis and a shift toward oxidative type I muscle fibers, improving muscle mass and function. HMB also showed potential benefits for whole-body health in both animals and humans.
population_specificity: Animals and humans (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hedonic qualities and consumption changes of a compote enriched with pea protein, hydrolyzed wheat gluten, and soluble fiber in elderly individuals, as well as its effects on fatigue, digestive comfort, and tolerance.
results_summary: The compote was rated as pleasant by most participants initially (91.6%) and remained so over three weeks (79.2%). Consumption was stable, averaging between 61.5% and 79.5% of the total quantity served, with no significant changes in other parameters.
population_specificity: Elderly volunteers aged 70-90 years in nursing homes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effects of soluble and insoluble fiber on the symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: Soluble fiber significantly improved global symptom assessment and abdominal pain scores in IBS patients, while insoluble fiber showed no improvement in any outcome. The meta-analysis indicated moderate heterogeneity and risk of bias across studies.
population_specificity: Outpatients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the effect of flaxseed consumption on blood pressure, including the influence of baseline blood pressure, type of flaxseed supplementation, and duration of supplementation.
results_summary: Flaxseed supplementation slightly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure, with greater improvements observed for whole flaxseed and durations exceeding 12 weeks.
population_specificity: Humans supplementing their habitual diet with flaxseed or its extracts (oil, lignans, fiber).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether agave inulin supplementation alters gastrointestinal microbiota composition and activity in healthy adults.
results_summary: Agave inulin significantly increased fecal Actinobacteria and Bifidobacterium, reduced Desulfovibrio, and tended to lower fecal 4-methylphenol and pH. It also showed positive associations with butyrate production and Bifidobacterium abundance.
population_specificity: Healthy adults (n = 29)
study_duration: 21 days per dosage period, with 7-day washouts between periods

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether dietary fiber intake modulates the association between alcohol intake and the risk of hormone-dependent cancers.
results_summary: The study found that alcohol intake was directly associated with hormone-dependent cancer risk, particularly breast cancer, but this association was attenuated among individuals with higher dietary fiber intake. Dietary fiber appeared to modulate the alcohol-cancer link, especially for prostate cancer.
population_specificity: 3,771 women and 2,771 men from the Supplémentation en Vitamines et Minéraux Antioxydants study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of fiber and prebiotic supplementation in enteral nutrition on diarrhea, fecal microbiota, and short-chain fatty acids.
results_summary: Fiber supplementation reduced diarrhea in patients receiving enteral nutrition, particularly in stable (non-critically ill) patients, but prebiotics did not show a significant effect on diarrhea incidence. The impact on fecal microbiota and SCFAs remained unclear.
population_specificity: Adult patients on exclusive enteral nutrition, including stable and critically ill subgroups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of supplemental meat and soybean biscuits on weight, lean body mass, morbidity, and nutritional status in drug-naïve, HIV-infected rural Kenyan women and their children.
results_summary: The study found that soybean biscuits provided more total and absorbable iron but had higher fiber and phytate contents, which may inhibit nutrient absorption. Clinical outcomes analysis was ongoing at the time of the abstract.
population_specificity: Drug-naïve, HIV-infected rural Kenyan women and their children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of ractopamine supplementation, castration method, and genotype on longissimus muscle fiber traits and pork quality.
results_summary: Ractopamine increased fiber IIX cross-sectional area and decreased glycolytic potential and pork tenderness. Immuno-castration resulted in more oxidative muscle fibers and slightly higher off-flavor scores compared to surgical castration. Genotype differences influenced pork color, glycolytic potential, and off-flavor.
population_specificity: Pigs (n=512) with varying genotypes (25% or 50% Piétrain) and castration methods (surgical or immuno-castration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of dietary fiber supplementation (polydextrose and soluble corn fiber) on the fecal microbiome's phylogenetic structure and functional capacity in healthy adults.
results_summary: Fiber supplementation shifted the Bacteroidetes:Firmicutes ratio, increased the relative abundance of Bacteroidetes, and altered bacterial gene abundances related to metabolism. Bacterial gene composition was more similar in participants consuming fibers compared to the no-fiber control.
population_specificity: Healthy adult men (n = 21)
effective_dosage: 21 g/day of polydextrose or soluble corn fiber

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of dietary fiber intake on serum urea and creatinine levels in individuals with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: Dietary fiber supplementation significantly reduced serum urea and creatinine levels in individuals with CKD, though the study noted significant interstudy heterogeneity for serum urea. The study also highlighted the lack of clinical trials on harder endpoints.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of FOS supplementation on constipation and biochemical parameters in elderly CAPD patients with chronic constipation.
results_summary: FOS significantly increased defecation frequency, improved feces appearance, and enhanced colonic transit without affecting biochemical parameters. Mild discomforts were reported but were well tolerated after dose adjustment.
population_specificity: Elderly continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) patients (5 males and 4 females) with chronic constipation.
study_duration: 30 days per treatment period, with a 14-day washout between treatments

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of baru almonds (a source of dietary fiber) on lipid profile and oxidation in mildly hypercholesterolemic subjects.
results_summary: Baru almond supplementation significantly reduced total cholesterol (-8.1%), LDL-c (-9.4%), and non-HDL-c (-8.1%) compared to placebo, but no significant changes were observed in oxidation biomarkers.
population_specificity: 20 mildly hypercholesterolemic subjects (total cholesterol mean ±SEM = 5.8 ± 0.2 mmol/L).
study_duration: Two 6-week intervention periods with a 4-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hydrolyzed whey protein supplementation accelerates satellite cell proliferation in human skeletal muscle after high-intensity eccentric exercise.
results_summary: The whey protein group showed increased satellite cell accumulation in type II fibers at 24 and 48 hours post-exercise, with a significant difference from the placebo group at 48 hours. Muscle damage markers (MVC, soreness, CK) were unaffected by supplementation.
population_specificity: 24 young, healthy subjects
effective_dosage: Not specified (hydrolyzed whey protein + carbohydrate vs. iso-caloric carbohydrate)
study_duration: Post-exercise recovery monitored up to 168 hours (7 days)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of fiber supplements, particularly soluble fiber and bran, in treating irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) through a systematic review of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Soluble fiber was found to be effective in treating IBS, with a significant reduction in symptoms (RR=0.83; NNT=7), while bran showed no significant benefit (RR=0.90). No evidence of harm from bran was found.
population_specificity: Adults with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficiency and tolerance of fiber-enriched orange juice in supplementing fiber intake in women.
results_summary: The fiber-enriched orange juice effectively increased total and soluble fiber intake to meet daily recommendations, with no changes in macronutrient or energy intake. Mild gastrointestinal symptoms (bloating, rumbles, flatulence) increased over time but were not intense.
population_specificity: 192 healthy adult women
effective_dosage: 400 mL of orange juice daily (fiber-enriched or placebo)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the benefits of supplementing dietary fiber in meat products to improve nutritional value and functional properties.
results_summary: The study found that adding dietary fiber to meat products enhances nutritional components, improves functional properties (e.g., water-holding capacity, emulsion stability), and may help prevent diseases like coronary heart disease and diabetes. It also increases cooking yield and economic benefits.
population_specificity: Frequent meat consumers (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review traditional and emerging treatments for IBS, including fiber supplementation, and assess their effectiveness and safety.
results_summary: The abstract mentions fiber supplementation as a traditional treatment for IBS but does not provide specific results regarding its efficacy. It highlights the complexity of IBS treatment and emerging therapies with better outcomes.
population_specificity: Young adults with IBS symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between dietary fiber intake (total, insoluble, soluble, and from various sources) and prostate cancer risk.
results_summary: The study found an inverse association between prostate cancer risk and total dietary fiber, insoluble fiber, and legume fiber intakes, but no significant association with soluble, cereal, vegetable, or fruit fiber intakes.
population_specificity: 3313 men from the SU.VI.MAX cohort who completed at least three 24-hour dietary records.
effective_dosage: Not specified (quartiles of energy-adjusted dietary fiber intake were analyzed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether post-exercise creatine monohydrate (CrM) consumption enhances body composition and muscle strength compared to resistance training alone in middle to older males.
results_summary: The study found no significant supplement interaction effects, indicating CrM did not enhance body composition or muscle strength beyond resistance training alone. Significant improvements were observed in muscle strength and body composition over time, but these were attributed to resistance training rather than CrM supplementation.
population_specificity: Middle to older males aged 55–70 years.
effective_dosage: Initial loading phase: 20 g/day CrM + 5 g/day CHO for 7 days; maintenance: ~8.8 g CrM + 5 g CHO on training days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence for or against the efficacy of glucomannan (a soluble fiber) in reducing body weight in overweight and obese individuals.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 8 RCTs showed no statistically significant weight loss with glucomannan compared to placebo (mean difference: -0.22 kg). Adverse events included abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, and constipation.
population_specificity: Overweight and/or obese participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how different physicochemical properties of pectin (a dietary fiber) and methods of supplementation affect appetite, energy intake, and metabolic responses.
results_summary: Gelled pectin significantly reduced appetite compared to other forms of pectin and delayed gastric emptying, though it did not affect subsequent energy intake. Different supplementation methods (capsules, liquid) resulted in distinct metabolic parameters, with capsules reducing energy intake more than liquid.
population_specificity: 29 subjects (21±2 years, BMI: 21.9±1.8 kg/m²)
effective_dosage: 10 g of pectin (bulking, viscous, gelled) in dairy-based liquid test products
study_duration: Single ingestion with measurements taken before and after fixed intervals (energy intake measured after 3 hours)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of dietary fiber in reducing the risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in Latino youth.
results_summary: The study found an inverse relationship between dietary fiber intake and visceral adipose tissue, metabolic syndrome, and insulin resistance, but noted inconsistencies in fiber definition and implementation that require further exploration.
population_specificity: Overweight Latino youth at high risk for T2DM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal number of half hitches for knot security, compare the performance of racking hitch knots using different suture materials, and evaluate biomechanical differences between racking hitch, Weston, and square knots.
results_summary: The racking hitch knot showed significantly higher loads to failure (359.6 N) compared to Weston (145.2 N) and square knots (77 N), with four half hitches improving knot security. FiberWire® #2 and Force Fiber™ #2 sutures performed better in load-to-failure tests, while Ethibond Excel™ showed minimal slippage during cyclic testing.
population_specificity: Not specified (biomechanical study using an Instron device, no human participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and potential benefits of dietary fiber in managing inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, and pouchitis) through randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found limited weak evidence for fiber's efficacy in improving disease outcomes in ulcerative colitis (3/10 studies) and pouchitis (1/1 study), but no benefit in Crohn's disease (0/12 studies). Some studies reported favorable physiological effects, such as improved fecal butyrate and reduced inflammation markers.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease, and pouchitis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of glucomannan, a water-soluble fiber supplement, for promoting weight loss in overweight and moderately obese individuals.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in weight loss, body composition, hunger/fullness, or lipid and glucose parameters between the glucomannan and placebo groups after 8 weeks. Glucomannan was well tolerated but did not demonstrate efficacy for weight loss or metabolic improvements.
population_specificity: Overweight and moderately obese individuals aged 18-65 with a BMI of 25-35 kg/m².
effective_dosage: 1.33 grams of glucomannan taken with 236.6 mL of water one hour before breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of chia supplementation on body composition, lipid profile, and blood glucose in overweight or obese individuals.
results_summary: Chia supplementation led to modest but significant reductions in body weight and waist circumference, improved lipid profile (reduced total cholesterol and VLDL-c, increased HDL-c) in individuals with abnormal initial values, but no changes in triglycerides, blood glucose, or LDL-C.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese men and women (ages ~48.8–51.4 years).
effective_dosage: 35 g of chia flour per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of drug-eluting electrospun fibers as a novel intravaginal delivery system for HIV prevention and treatment, addressing design constraints and user preferences.
results_summary: The study found that electrospun fibers can deliver multiple antiretroviral agents with controlled release, offering flexibility for pericoital or sustained use, but noted challenges in vaginal deployment, retention, and safety interactions with mucosal environments.
population_specificity: Women at risk of HIV infection (theoretical population, not explicitly studied in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of resistant maltodextrin (RMD) in reducing body fat accumulation across different high-fat diet models in rodents.
results_summary: RMD supplementation (2.07 g/kg) significantly reduced total body fat in three high-fat diet models, except for a condensed-milk-added 40%-fat diet. The study recommended specific high-fat diet models (23% fat with/without milk and milk-free 40% fat) for future antiobesity evaluations of RMD or other fiber-rich products.
population_specificity: Rodents (specific species not mentioned)
